Award.AwardTitle: Stable Isotope Insights into Shellfish Consumption and Transport

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In partnership with several tribal organizations in California, this research examines the role of shellfish in the diets of pre-contact Native Californians, and by extension, the maintenance and evolution of social networks and organizations. Shellfish is common in archaeological sites on San Francisco Bay, and judging by the huge shellmounds that formed up to several millenia ago, was a major dietary staple for people living in this region. Somewhat surprising, however, are large amounts of shellfish at inland archaeological sites that are up to dozens of kilometers from the bay. These food resources would have been carried on the backs of people, without means of refrigeration, prompting the question, what role did shellfish play in inland subsistence economies? Were they staples in the diet, important but minor sources of nutrients such as iodine, fallback/starvation foods, or part of ritual or feasting events? The project will provide information on human ecological adaptation and organization of trade networking. It will also create and enhance educational and training opportunities for students, develop a museum display open to the public, and enhance collaboration between archaeologists and particular descendant groups.

The human skeleton is synthesized from the foods we eat. Relative to terrestrial foods, marine resources contain distinctive chemical and stable isotopic signatures. These become embedded in growing skeletal tissues, including teeth. The research team will take advantage of advances in mass spectrometry that facilitate analysis of small micro-samples of dentinal collagen and shell carbonate. Micro-sampling of teeth and shells will allow them to trace the transportation and consumption of shellfish across different people, different seasons, and across different time scales within a personâ€™s life. The new data will allow the team to test particular models about the role that shellfish played in human diets, across a range of distances from San Francisco Bay. Together, the research will provide new insights into the diversity of human ecological adaptations within a complex environment, the nature of inter-annual and inter-individual variation in ancient human diets, the role of micro- and macro-nutrients in diets, and the development of social networks in providing access to estuarine resources in more inland settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project sought to understand the role that shellfish played within the lives of precontact Native American populations in Central California (ca. 2000 to 300 years ago). Shellfish remains from San Francisco Bay are a common component of archaeological sites, even in locations that are far inland where such shellfish must have been imported through either trade or direct acquisition. Lacking pack animals and mechanized transportation, such items would have been largely carried by people. In some cases, the distances over which shellfish were moved would have incurred greater caloric costs than the shellfish would have provided nutritionally.

                Given these facts, this research sought to address what motivations people may have had to transport shellfish to inland locations. Hypotheses include that shellfish may have been important for ceremonial or social events, as an exotic food. Alternatively, shellfish may have been valuable for their micro- or macro-nutrients, such as iodine or protein. The importance of such ceremonial events and/or nutrients may have varied throughout the seasons and from year-to-year. Towards this end, we sought to understand whether shellfish were traded year-round or only during certain seasons, and whether they were used every year or only in certain years, using stable isotope signatures in various material remains from archaeological sites.

            In collaboration with several Native Californian tribes from the region, archaeologists from private industry (Cultural Resource Management companies), and archaeologists at the university (including undergraduate and graduate students), the project brought together different entities, each with interests in ancient subsistence practices. Data analyses are still underway, however, some results are evident thus far, and have been published in a series of articles and conference presentations. In short, we found that while shellfish were exploited year-round in bayside archaeological sites, they were imported inland almost exclusively in the winter season. As well, shellfish seem to have been consumed in inland sites in low amounts, but with fluctuations in intensity from year to year, suggesting such foods were not part of annually-held ceremonies, but may have served as a type of back-up food during the lean season when other resources, such as acorns and large game were limited in availability. In this respect, shellfish may have provided a key macro-nutrient in the winter, likely protein, that was in short supply, justifying any caloric shortfall.

                Funding for this project helped support the collection of data for three different PhD dissertations, and gave those graduate students experience in archaeometic research, working collaboratively with different interest groups, and mentoring of undergraduate students. Nine different undergraduate students worked on different portions of the overall research project, providing them with valuable experience in laboratory settings. Seven of these students presented papers or posters at conferences, providing them with experience in research dissemination and professional practice in archaeology. Several of these students now work professionally within the Cultural Resource Management sector in California, or have entered graduate school to pursue advanced Masters and PhD degrees. Finally, results will also be incorporated into a museum display targeted for the general public within the Anthropology Museum at UC Davis. Unfortunately, displays are currently on hold due to a seismic renovation project within the building that normally houses the Anthropology Department. However, upon completion of the renovation project, likely in 2026, the display will go up and will be visible to the public for a minimum of two years.
